title: 110_s94
content: The Gasoline Consumer Anti-price-gouging Protection Act includes provisions for protecting consumers against price gouging, justifiable price increases, emergency proclamations, enforcement by the Federal Trade Commission, penalties, and definitions. SEC. 2 of the Gasoline Consumer Anti-price-gouging Protection Act prohibits suppliers from unreasonably increasing gasoline or petroleum distillate prices in specified areas under Presidential proclamations or Federal Trade Commission emergency orders. SEC. 3 of the Gasoline Consumer Anti-price-gouging Protection Act outlines justifiable price increases for gasoline or petroleum distillates, attributing them to factors such as wholesale cost, replacement costs, operational costs, and market conditions. Mitigating factors are also considered to determine violations of price gouging. The President or the Federal Trade Commission can issue emergency proclamations or orders in response to abnormal market disruptions. These proclamations or orders specify the duration and reason for their necessity. Emergency proclamations or orders can be issued by the President or the Federal Trade Commission in response to abnormal market disruptions. These proclamations or orders may specify the area or region to which they apply and have limitations on their duration, not exceeding 30 consecutive days and renewable for another 30 days. They can also apply to a period of up to 7 days before the event necessitating the proclamation or order. The Federal Trade Commission enforces emergency proclamations or orders in response to abnormal market disruptions, specifying the area and duration of the measures. The Federal Trade Commission enforces emergency proclamations or orders in response to abnormal market disruptions, specifying the area and duration of the measures. Section 2 of this Act empowers the FTC to enforce violations as unfair or deceptive acts. The Commission will prevent suppliers from violating the Act using the same powers and penalties as under the Federal Trade Commission Act. Regulations must be prescribed within 180 days of enactment. The Federal Trade Commission will prescribe regulations to implement the Act within 180 days of enactment. SEC. 6. PENALTIES. Civil penalties for violations of the Act range from $500,000 for small business gasoline marketers to $5,000,000 for other suppliers. Penalties are assessed similarly to those under the Federal Trade Commission Act, with each day of violation considered a separate offense. The seriousness of the violation and efforts to mitigate it are taken into account when determining penalties. The violation of the Act can result in a criminal penalty of up to $1,000,000 fine or 2 years imprisonment, enforced by the Attorney General or Department of Justice. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "abnormal market disruption" refers to potential price increases in gasoline or petroleum distillates due to various factors like extreme weather or civil unrest. "Supplier" is defined as anyone involved in selling or distributing these products. "Unconscionable amount" signifies a significant price hike for gasoline or petroleum distillates by a supplier covered under section 2. The Act defines "abnormal market disruption" as potential price increases in gasoline or petroleum distillates due to factors like extreme weather or civil unrest. A supplier cannot increase the price of gasoline or petroleum distillates to an unconscionable amount, which substantially exceeds the average price in the 30-day period before the sale, competitors' prices during the emergency period, and cannot be justified by certain factors. SEC. 8. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act will be in effect once the Federal Trade Commission issues a final rule under section 5(c) and publishes it in the Federal Register.
